Defendants' Attorneys: Sabrina Berdux, Kaitlyn Murphy, and Margaret Baumgartner. Raymond Rolland and Renee Rosenblit. Also appearing: Katie Tertocha. case_data.name: Pierce v. County of San Francisco
case_data.plaintiff_description: Pre-trial detainees at a San Francisco County jail, on behalf of a putative class of themselves and others similarly situated.
case_data.summary:
This case concerns allegations by pretrial detainees of insufficient access to sunlight, fresh air, and recreation time, as well as being subjected to illegal strip searches.

On November 21, 2019, the Plaintiff, a pretrial detainee, filed a putative class action complaint on behalf of herself and all other similarly situated inmates in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the County of San Francisco (“County”), as well as named and unnamed officials and employees of the San Francisco Sheriff’s Department (“SFSD”).  Represented by private counsel, Plaintiff sued under 42 USC § 1983 based on alleged violations of the Fourth Amendment's prohibition on unreasonable searches and seizures, the Eighth Amendment's prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment, and the Fourteenth Amendment's substantive due process protections. The Plaintiff also brought claims under state law.

Specifically, the complaint alleged that the county had a policy whereby female deputies at a County Jail conducted random, unnecessary, and unjustified visual body cavity searches of pretrial and convicted female inmates in the presence and direct view of male deputies, and subsequently searched and destroyed their property. It also alleged that, at another County Jail, pretrial and post-conviction inmates were denied any opportunity for fresh air or time outside for exercise or recreation. Plaintiff sought compensatory and punitive damages, attorney’s fees, and declaratory and injunctive relief. The case was assigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White.

On April 3, 2020, Defendants filed a motion to dismiss. On May 1, 2020, Plaintiff, along with three others, filed an amended complaint. The parties engaged in settlement negotiations, but these were ultimately unsuccessful. On October 9, 2020, Defendants filed a motion to dismiss Plaintiffs' amended complaint. This motion was denied by Judge White on January 14, 2021. Specifically, Judge White found that Plaintiffs could allege that systemic deprivation of outdoor time and cross-gender viewing of unclothed body cavity searches violated their constitutional rights, and that Plaintiffs had met their burden at this stage to overcome Defendants' qualified immunity.

On November 5, 2021, Plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint. This complaint named five individual plaintiffs (all current or former pretrial detainees) acting on behalf of the class, and reasserted the claims related to the denial of outdoor recreation time and cross-gender visual body cavity searches, in violation of the U.S. Constitution and state law.

The parties subsequently filed a motion to sever the case into two sets of claims, one based on recreation time and the other on the searches. The court granted the motion on December 21, 2021. Plaintiffs then filed motions to certify a class for both sets of claims.

On August 12, 2022, Defendants filed motions for summary judgment on both the search and recreation claims. Plaintiffs also moved for summary judgment on the recreation claim.

On December 5, 2022, the court granted summary judgment for Defendants. 2022 WL 17418974. Regarding the outdoor recreation claim, the court found that the jail provided otherwise meaningful indoor exercise and recreation to its inmates, and thus did not violate the Fourteenth Amendment. The court acknowledged that the facility did not provide outdoor recreation opportunities to pretrial detainees, but concluded that this alone did not amount to punishment. As for the cross-gender search claim, the court conceded that male deputies were sometimes in a position to have viewed the strip searches, but found that only infrequent or casual observance of the inmates was insufficient to constitute an infringement of the inmates’ Fourteenth Amendment rights. The court also denied the motions for class certification as moot.

On December 5, 2022, judgment was entered in favor of the Defendants, and the case was closed.
case_data.summary_short: This case concerns allegations of insufficient outdoor recreation time and improper strip searches experienced by pretrial detainees in a San Francisco County jail. A pre-trial detainee filed a putative class action complaint on November 21, 2019, against the County of San Francisco, as well as named and unnamed officials and employees of the San Francisco Sheriff’s Department, in the Northern District of California, alleging violations of the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as state law. Plaintiffs’ final amended complaint was filed on November 5, 2021, naming five individual plaintiffs acting on behalf of the class. The court ultimately granted summary judgment for Defendants on December 5, 2022, and the case is closed.

documents.title: Order Denying Defendants’ Motion to Dismiss
documents.text:
Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 1 of 8
 
1   
2   
3   
4  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
6   
JILLIAN PIERCE, NICOLE WWAD,  Case No.  19-cv-07659-JSW    
7 
VINCENT KEITH BELL, on behalf of   
herself and all other similarly situated,   
8 
ORDER DENYING DEFENDANTS’ 
Plaintiffs,  MOTION TO DISMISS 
9 
v.  Re: Dkt. No. 45 
10 
 
COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO, VICKI 
11 
HENNESSEY, MICHELE FISHER, and 
 
DOES 1-50, 
12 
a 
truo inro 13  Defendants. 
Cfi  
 tla  
cC 14 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    Now before the Court is the motion to dismiss filed by Defendants City and County of San 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Francisco and Vicki Hennessy, Sheriff Paul Miyamoto, and Michelle Fisher (collectively 
S d nr “Defendants”).  Defendants move to dismiss all claims under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
ee 17 
th
intr
Uo 12(b)(6).  Having reviewed the pleadings and the record in this case, the Court DENIES 
N 18 
Defendants’ motion to dismiss. 
19 
BACKGROUND 
20 
  Plaintiffs are former and current pretrial detainees at San Francisco Jail No. 2 operated by 
21 
Defendants.  Plaintiffs allege that they have been deprived rights secured by the United States 
22 
Constitution and state law based on their deprivation of outdoor recreation opportunities and for 
23 
being regularly subjected to male deputies watching unclothed body cavity searches.   
24 
  Additional specific facts shall be addressed in the body of this order. 
25 
ANALYSIS 
26 
A.  Legal Standard on Motion to Dismiss. 
27 
A motion to dismiss is proper under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) where the 
28 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 2 of 8
 
1  pleadings fail to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.  A court’s “inquiry is limited to 
2  the allegations in the complaint, which are accepted as true and construed in the light most 
3  favorable to the plaintiff.”  Lazy Y Ranch Ltd. v. Behrens, 546 F.3d 580, 588 (9th Cir. 2008).  Even 
4  under the liberal pleading standard of Rule 8(a)(2), “a plaintiff’s obligation to provide the 
5  ‘grounds’ of his ‘entitle[ment] to relief’ requires more than labels and conclusions, and a 
6  formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action will not do.”  Bell Atlantic Corp. v. 
7  Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 555 (2007) (citing Papasan v. Allain, 478 U.S. 265, 286 (1986)).  
8  Pursuant to Twombly, a plaintiff must not merely allege conduct that is conceivable but must 
9  instead allege “enough facts to state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face.”  Id. at 570.  “A 
10  claim has facial plausibility when the plaintiff pleads factual content that allows the court to draw 
11  the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.”  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 
12  556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (citing Twombly, 550 U.S. at 556).     
a 
tr in
uoro 13  If the allegations are insufficient to state a claim, a court should grant leave to amend, 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  unless amendment would be futile.  See, e.g., Reddy v. Litton Indus., Inc., 912 F.2d 291, 296 (9th 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Cir. 1990); Cook, Perkiss & Liehe, Inc. v. N. Cal. Collection Serv., Inc., 911 F.2d 242, 246-47 (9th 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Cir. 1990).  However, “[t]he district court’s discretion to deny leave to amend is … broad where 
S d nr
ee 17  plaintiff has previously amended the complaint.”  Allen v. City of Beverly Hills, 911 F.2d 367, 373 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  (9th Cir. 1990) (internal quotations and citation omitted). 
19  B.  Outdoor Recreation Claims. 
20  Plaintiffs allege that Defendants deny them and all prisoners in County Jail No. 2 access to 
21  outdoor recreation and direct sunlight based on the jail’s deliberate design and logistical 
22  limitations.  The Court finds that the right to some form of outdoor recreation for pretrial detainees 
23  and prisoners alike is clearly established.   
24    The binding cases addressing the rights of prisoners to recreation and access to daylight 
25  support the contention that some sort of outdoor recreation is required.  See, e.g., Spain v. 
26  Procunier, 600 F.2d 189, 199 (9th Cir. 1979) (holding that “[t]here is substantial agreement 
27  among the cases in this area that some form of regular outdoor exercise is extremely important to 
28  the psychological and physical well being of the inmates.”); Toussaint v. Yockey, 722 F.2d 1490, 
2 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 3 of 8
 
1  1492 (9th Cir. 1984) (holding that under certain conditions, the deprivation of outdoor exercise to 
2  inmates raises serious constitutional issues); see also Allen v. Sakai, 48 F.3d 1082, 1084 (9th Cir. 
3  1994) (“After Spain and Toussaint, defendants cannot legitimately claim that their duty to provide 
4  regular outdoor exercise to [the plaintiff] was not clearly established.”).   
5  It is clearly established that “[e]xercise is one of the basic human necessities protected by 
6  the Eighth Amendment . . . Moreover, the Fourteenth Amendment requires that pre-trial detainees 
7  not be denied adequate opportunities for exercise without legitimate governmental objective.”  
8  Pierce v. County of Orange, 526 F.3d 1190, 1211-12 (9th Cir. 2008).  Furthermore, the lack of 
9  outdoor space in the facility may be solely a logistical problem, and, without more, the facility 
10  design “cannot justify serious civil rights violations such as the ‘deprivation of a basic human 
11  need.’”  Shorter v. Baca, 895 F.3d 1176, 1186 (9th Cir. 2018) (quoting Allen, 48 F.3d at 1185). 
12  Accordingly, the Court finds that Plaintiffs may allege that their constitutional rights were 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  violated as a result of the systematic deprivation of outdoor recreation time. 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  C.  Unclothed Body Cavity Searches Claims. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Plaintiffs also allege that their constitutional rights secured by the Fourteenth Amendment 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  have been violated as a result of being subjected to unclothed body cavity searches in view of 
S d nr
ee 17  male guards.  A court must examine any search to determine its reasonableness under the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  circumstances.  Cross-gender strip searches in the absence of an emergency may violate an 
19  inmate’s right under the Fourteenth Amendment to be free from unreasonable searches.  See Byrd 
20  v. Maricopa County Sheriff’s Dep’t, 629 F.3d 1135, 1146 (9th Cir. 2011) (en banc).  The Court in 
21  Byrd reaffirmed its “longstanding recognition that ‘[t]he desire to shield one’s unclothed figure 
22  from [the] view of strangers, and particularly strangers of the opposite sex, is impelled by 
23  elementary self-respect and personal dignity.”  Id. at 1141 (quoting York v. Story, 324 F.2d 450, 
24  455 (9th Cir. 1963)).   
25  Whether any particular set of circumstances makes a search reasonable under the 
26  Fourteenth Amendment requires a case-by-case factual analysis which balances “the need for the 
27  particular search against the invasion of personal rights that the search entails.”  Id. (citing Bell v. 
28  Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 559 (1979)).  The Court must balance and consider the following factors:  
3 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 4 of 8
 
1  “(1) the scope of the particular intrusion, (2) the manner in which it is conducted, (3) the 
2  justification for initiating it, and (4) the place in which it is conducted.”  Id. (citations omitted).  
3  Depending upon the circumstances and the specific facts of any particular search, the examining 
4  court may recognize “that not all strip search procedures will be reasonable; some could be 
5  excessive, vindictive, harassing, or unrelated to any legitimate penological interest.  Thus our task 
6  is to consider carefully the reasonableness of [the prison’s] strip search policies.”  Michenfelder v. 
7  Sumner, 860 F.2d 328, 332 (9th Cir. 1988).   
8  Here, Plaintiffs allege that on at least two occasions, they were subjected to unclothed 
9  body cavity searches while male sheriff’s deputies were permitted to watch, with one deputy 
10  commenting that he did not have a girlfriend and had found the plaintiffs attractive.  (See FAC ¶¶ 
11  26-29.)  Plaintiffs allege that they were in their pod at the time of the searches, and that they were 
12  forced to undress, squat, cough, and spread open their vaginas and anuses, and lift their breasts for 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  visual inspection.  (See id. at ¶¶ 26, 28.)  They allege the searches were conducted indiscriminately 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  and occurred early in the morning and that they were woken up from sleep in order to be searched.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  (See id.)  The allegations do not indicate there was any particular emergency or urgency 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  necessitating the searches.  These allegations further indicate that the male officers did not 
S d nr
ee 17  incidentally view the unclothed female inmates, but rather were watching for at least some time.   
th
intr
Uo
N 18  The reasonableness of the search must be determined by the case-by-case weighing and 
19  balancing of the facts.  However, as alleged, Plaintiffs have set out sufficient facts to make out a 
20  claim that the viewing of the unclothed cavity searches by male deputies may violate their 
21  constitutionally protected rights under the Fourteenth Amendment.  Accordingly, the Court finds 
22  that Plaintiffs may allege that their constitutional rights were violated as a result of the cross-
23  gender viewing of unclothed body cavity searches. 
24  D.  Qualified Immunity. 
25  In their motion to dismiss, Defendants argue that the officers involved in the alleged  
26  deprivations of Plaintiffs’ constitutional rights are entitled to qualified immunity for their conduct.  
27  Qualified immunity “shields an officer from suit when she makes a decision that, even if 
28  constitutionally deficient, reasonably misapprehends the law governing the circumstances she 
4 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 5 of 8
 
1  confronted.”  Brosseau v. Haugen, 543 U.S. 194, 198 (2004).  A claim for qualified immunity 
2  requires the court to evaluate the defense using a two-step inquiry in Saucier v. Katz, 533 U.S. 194 
3  (2001).  The first step is to determine whether, given the undisputed facts, the officers violated a 
4  constitutional right.  Pearson v. Callahan, 555 U.S. 223, 231 (2009).  Under the second step of 
5  Saucier, the issue is whether the allegedly violated constitutional rights was “clearly established” 
6  in the specific factual context confronting the officers.  See Saucier, 533 U.S. at 202.  “If an 
7  official could reasonably have believed her actions were legal in light of clearly established law 
8  and the information she possessed at the time, she is protected by qualified immunity.”  Franklin 
9  v. Fox, 312 F.3d 423, 437 (9th Cir. 2002).  Courts may choose which prong of this analysis to 
10  address first.  See Pearson, 555 U.S. at 236-39.  Examining the second prong first may “expedite 
11  the resolution of the case” because the second prong may be decided as a matter of law.  Morales 
12  v. Fry, 873 F.3d 817, 822-23 (9th Cir. 2017).   
a 
tr in
uoro 13  The Court begins and ends its analysis with the second factor.   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  A federal right is “clearly established” when, at the time of the official’s conduct, the law 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  was “sufficiently clear that every reasonable official would understand” that what he or she was 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  doing was unlawful.  District of Columbia v. Wesby, 138 S. Ct. 527, 589 (2018) (citations and 
S d nr
ee 17  quotations omitted).  For a right to be clearly established, the law must be “settled”—the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  constitutionality “beyond debate”—with a sufficiently clear foundation in “then-existing 
19  precedent.”  Id.; Hunter v. Bryant, 502 U.S. 224, 228 (1991).  It is not enough that the right in 
20  question is “suggested” by precedent existing at the time of the official’s challenged conduct.  
21  Wesby, 138 S. Ct. at 590.  Rather, a rule must be dictated by controlling authority or a “robust 
22  consensus of cases of persuasive authority.”  Id. at 589-90 (citations and quotations omitted).  The 
23  precedent must be sufficiently clear so that “every reasonable official would interpret it to 
24  establish the particular rule the plaintiff seeks to apply.”  Id. (citation omitted).  The Court must 
25  therefore ask whether every reasonable official in Defendants’ positions would have known that 
26  their specific actions were unconstitutional, given the particular facts that they faced and the 
27  “precedent on the books.”  Hamby v. Hammond, 821 F.3d 1085, 1091 (9th Cir. 2016) (citation and 
28  quotation omitted); see Mullenix v. Luna, 136 S. Ct. 305, 309 (2015) (noting that the second-prong 
5 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 6 of 8
 
1  inquiry depends “very much on the facts of each case”).  The burden is on the party contesting 
2  qualified immunity to show that a law was clearly established at the time of an alleged violation.  
3  Davis v. Scherer, 468 U.S. 183, 197-98 (1984).   
4    Because the Court has found that Plaintiffs have sufficiently alleged facts to state causes of 
5  action for violation of their constitutional rights to outdoor recreational opportunities and freedom 
6  from the non-emergent cross-gender cavity searches, the Court finds that, at the pleading stage, 
7  Plaintiffs have met their burden to present allegations that “state a claim for violation of clearly 
8  established law.”  Mitchell v. Forsyth¸ 472 US. 511, 526 (1985).  The Court finds that Defendants 
9  are not, at this procedural stage, entitled to the defense of qualified immunity.1 
10  E.  Bane Act Claims. 
11  Defendants also contend that California Government Code section 844.6, which grants 
12  public entities immunity for injuries to prisoners, bars liability against the City for Plaintiffs’ Bane 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Act claims.  This provision applies equally to preconviction detainees as it does convicted 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  prisoners.  See Cal. Gov’t Code § 844; see also Sahley v. County of San Diego, 69 Cal. App. 3d 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  347, 349 (1977) (holding that “preconviction detainee awaiting trial” who has been “booked and 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  arraigned” was considered a “’prisoner’ for purposes of governmental immunity”).   
S d nr
ee 17  California Government Code section 820.6 provides that “[i]f a public employee acts in 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  good faith, without malice, and under the apparent authority of an enactment that is 
19  unconstitutional, invalid, or inapplicable, he is not liable for an injury caused thereby.”  Under this 
20  section, “‘good faith’ reflects a subjective intention to act under the authority of the governing 
21  enactment, and to enforce or comply with those rules.”  O’Toole v. Superior Court, 140 Cal. App. 
22  4th 488, 505 (2006).  Defendants argue that because Plaintiffs have not pled any facts to 
23 
 
24 
1 Defendants also argue that the Court should dismiss the claims against the individual defendants 
in their individual capacities.  However, a supervisor may be held liable where there is “a 
25 
sufficient causal connection between the supervisor’s wrongful conduct and the constitutional 
violation.”  Henry A. v. Willden, 678 F.3d 991, 1003-04 (9th Cir. 2012) (quoting Starr v. Baca, 
26 
652 F.3d 1202, 1207 (9th Cir. 2011)).  Because Plaintiffs allege that the individual defendants had 
ultimate responsibility for the policy and training in the County jails, they may seek to hold the 
27 
individuals accountable for the failure to train, supervise, and control their subordinates regarding 
cavity searches and for failure to provide outdoor recreation opportunities pursuant to the County 
28 
jails’ policy, custom, or practice. 
6 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 7 of 8
 
1  demonstrate malicious intent by the Defendants and because no constitutional violations occurred, 
2  they should be found immune from liability.   
3    However, Plaintiffs do not allege that the conduct was taken in an effort to enforce a law or 
4  policy, but rather, allege that the conduct was a clear violation of well-established law.  The good 
5  faith immunity for carrying out a constitutional law or policy is not applicable under these 
6  circumstances. 
7    Defendants also contend that Plaintiffs may not proceed as potential class representatives 
8  because they failed to present their claims properly under the Claims Act.  In order to comply with 
9  the procedural requirements, a plaintiff in a potential class action must present a timely claim on 
10  behalf of the class that includes the name, address, and other specific information concerning the 
11  representative plaintiff and sufficient information to identify the class itself.  See City of San Jose 
12  v. Superior Court, 12 Cal. 3d 447, 452 (1974).  Plaintiffs are obligated to provide the descriptions 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  of injury or damage or loss so far as it may be known at the time of the presentation of the claim.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  See Blair v. Superior Court, 218 Cal. App. 3d 221, 224 (1990).  The policy underlying the claims 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  presentation requirements is to afford proper notice to public entities so as to permit early 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  investigation and evaluation of the claim without incurring the expense of litigation.  See San Jose, 
S d nr
ee 17  12 Cal. 3d at 452. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18    Here, it appears that Plaintiff Pierce filed multiple claims alleging that she was being 
19  deprived proper recreation opportunities.  Although she did not specify that the recreation should 
20  be made possible outdoors, the Court finds she provided multiple grievances giving the City 
21  sufficient notice that a reasonable investigation and evaluation of the claims could have been made 
22  without incurring the expense of litigation.  The Court also finds that the grievances were in 
23  substantial compliance with the requirements to proceed on behalf of a class.  See, e.g., Craft v. 
24  County of San Bernadino, 2006 WL 4941829, at *4-6 (C.D. Cal. Mar. 23, 2006) (“The fact that 
25  class representatives Craft and Hardy did not file a California Tort Claim prior to filing of the 
26  instant lawsuit does not serve to foreclose their ability to pursue any of the state law claims 
27  pressed in their complaint as one of the class representatives did submit a class claim that was in 
28  substantial compliance with Government Code section 910.”).  California Government Code 
7 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 56     Filed 01/14/21     Page 8 of 8
 
1  section 910 does not require claimants to describe all indebtedness, obligation, injury, damage, or 
2  loss incurred.  Rather, claimants are obligated to provide descriptions of indebtedness, obligation, 
3  injury, damage, or loss so far as it may be known at the time of presentation of the claim.  See 
4  Blair v. Superior Court, 218 Cal. App. 3d 221, 224 (1990) (“As long as these general elements are 
5  present, it is not necessary that the claim comply with formal pleading standards.”).  The Court 
6  finds that the fifteen grievances filed by Plaintiff Pierce are sufficient to give notice of the claims 
7  presented here. 
8  CONCLUSION 
9    Based on the foregoing, the Court DENIES Defendants’ motion to dismiss. 
10   
11  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
12  Dated:  January14, 2021 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  ______________________________________

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 1     Filed 11/20/19     Page 1 of 16
 
Andrew Chan Kim (SBN 315331) 
1  2603 Barclay Way 
Belmont, CA 94002 
2 
T: (650) 339-2005 
chan.a.kim@gmail.com 
3 
 
Attorney for Plaintiff 
4 
 
 
5 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
 
6 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
 
7 
SAN FRANCISCO DIVISION 
 
8 
 
 
9 
  )   
JILLIAN PIERCE, on behalf of herself and  )  Case No.:  
10 
all others similarly situated,  )   
  )  CLASS ACTION 
11 
  Plaintiff,  )   
  )  COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES, 
12 
  vs.  )  DECLARATORY & INJUNCTIVE 
  )  RELIEF, AND DEMAND FOR JURY 
13 
COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO, San  )  TRIAL 
Francisco Sheriff’s Department Sheriff  )   
14 
VICKI HENNESSY, San Francisco Sheriff’s )  1.  42 U.S.C. § 1983 – Civil Rights Violations 
Department Chief Deputy MICHELE  )  2.  42 U.S.C. § 1983 – Monell and 
15 
FISHER, and County of San Francisco  )  Supervisory Liability  
employees DOES 1-50, Jointly and Severally, )    3.  California Constitution, Article I, § 13 
16 
  )  4.  California Constitution, Article I, § 17 
  Defendant(s).  )  5.  California Civil Code § 52.1(b) – State 
17 
)  Civil Rights Violations 
)  6.  California Penal Code § 2644  
18 
)  7.  Intentional Infliction of Emotional Distress 
 
) 
19 
)   
20    Plaintiff and all other similarly situated persons, by and through her attorney, for her 
21  Complaint against Defendants, states the following: 
22  INTRODUCTION 
23    1.   On or about November 20, 2018, female deputies at the San Francisco County Jail 
24  #2 conducted an unnecessary and unjustified visual body cavity search of pretrial and convicted 
25  female inmates in the presence and direct view of at least three, and up to seven or more, male 
26  deputies. A similar, random, and unreasonable visual body cavity search of female inmates was 
27  conducted in front of male deputies about a month prior. Upon information and belief, these 
28  searches have occurred in D-Pod, B-Pod, and possibly E-Pod. Moreover, San Francisco County 
PLAINTIFF’S CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES, DECLARATORY & INJUNCTIVE RELIEF, AND 
 
1

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW     Document 1     Filed 11/20/19     Page 2 of 16
 
1  Jail #2 denies all pretrial and convicted inmates any opportunities for fresh air or time outside for 
2  exercise or recreation in violation of Title 15 of the California Code of Regulations § 1065, and 
3  the inmates’ Fourteenth and Eighth Amendment rights, respectively. These inmates, some of 
4  whom are pretrial and have been incarcerated for as long as six or seven years, have never seen 
5  the sun or felt the wind’s breeze in the entire duration of their incarceration.  
6  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
7    2.  This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 
8  1343(a)(3)-(4) because it is being brought to obtain compensatory and punitive damages for the 
9  deprivations, under color of state law, of the rights of citizens of the United States that are 
10  secured by the United States Constitution, pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §§ 1983 and 1988. This action 
11  is brought pursuant to the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States

1  PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
2  1.  The City and County of San Francisco operates active jails where it houses pretrial 
3  detainees and convicted prisoners.  
4  2.  San Francisco County Jail #2, located at 425 7th Street in San Francisco, houses up 
5  to 392 persons and is the only jail in the City and County of San Francisco that houses women.  
6  3.  Pretrial detainees—some with years long stays in the jail—have no access to outdoor 
7  recreation or access to sunlight, which causes physical detriments and severe mental anguish. The 
8  City and County of San Francisco, by policy, practice or custom, denies all pretrial detainees and 
9  convicted prisoners any opportunities for fresh air, direct sunlight, or time outside for exercise or 
10  recreation, or otherwise any meaningful recreation, in violation of Title 15 of the California Code of 
11  Regulations § 1065, and the prisoners’ Fourteenth and Eighth Amendment rights, respectively. 
12  These prisoners, some of whom are pretrial and have been incarcerated for as long as six or seven 
13  years, have never seen the sun or felt the wind’s breeze in the entire duration of their incarceration 
14  except very briefly during transports to the hospital, another facility, or to court. 
15  4.  Female pretrial detainees at County Jail #2 suffered further emotional anguish when 
16  female sheriff’s deputies at the jail forced them on at least two occasions to submit to unclothed 
17  body cavity searches while male deputies looked on. On or about November 20, 2018, female 
18  deputies at the San Francisco County Jail #2 conducted an unnecessary and unjustified visual 
19  body cavity search of pretrial and convicted female prisoners in the presence and direct view of at 
20  least three, and up to seven or more, male deputies. A similar, random, and unreasonable visual 
21  body cavity search of female prisoners was conducted in front of male deputies about a month 
22  prior. Upon information and belief, these searches have occurred in D-Pod, B-Pod, and possibly E-
23  Pod.  
24  JURISDICTION AND VENUE

Lack of Outdoor Recreation

22.  Jillian Pierce spent two years as a pretrial detainee in County Jail #2. Nicole Wade

22  awaiting trial. While incarcerated, they are denied any and all access to outdoor recreation and 
23  direct sunlight.

24

25

and infrequent. In 2018 and 2019, prisoners went to the gym on an average of once a month and 
3 
for an hour and a half at most. Prisoners in administrative segregation and prisoners housed in C-
4 
Pod are categorically denied gym access except on very rare and random occasions.

6

18  depression, and skin discoloration. Plaintiffs suffered acne, unhealthy weight gain, and/or other

20  risk of serious harm. Research shows direct sunlight provides benefits beyond visual comfort and

21

22

23

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW   Document 114   Filed 12/05/22   Page 2 of 10
 
1  BACKGROUND 
2    The City and County of San Francisco designed and constructed County Jail No. 2 (“CJ2”) 
3  located at 725 7th Street in San Francisco, without outdoor recreation space.  Initially the building 
4  was designated as a work furlough facility, but it is now utilized exclusively as a jail.  All pretrial 
5  detainees housed in CJ2 have not been provided outdoor recreation opportunities since 1994 when 
6  the facility opened.  Plaintiffs, past and present pretrial detainees at CJ2, allege that the County has 
7  a pattern and practice of deliberately denying detainees meaningful recreational opportunities.  
8  Although CJ2 has a gym and an atrium, Plaintiffs allege that neither provides direct sunlight and 
9  that, prior to the onset of Covid-19, pretrial detainees were routinely taken to the gym at nighttime 
10  after the sun had set.  The atrium provides filtered light and no fresh air.  Plaintiffs allege that the 
11  space was not made available to pretrial detainees regularly, and prior to Covid-19, was only made 
12  available for the limited purpose of legal visits.  Plaintiffs allege that most pretrial detainees have 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  never been to the atrium.  Post onset of Covid-19, Plaintiffs allege that the gym has not been used 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  for inmate recreation.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    Separately, Plaintiffs also allege that between March 30, 2018 and August 21, 2020, 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Defendants indiscriminately subjected 414 female pretrial detainees housed in CJ2 to 
S d nr
ee 17  unreasonable and non-emergent unclothed body cavity searches in the presence of male deputies 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  and other women.  Plaintiffs claim that these searches occurred eight times in less than two years, 
19  thereby establishing a pattern or practice of subjecting the female pretrial detainees to searches in 
20  violation of their constitutional rights and in violation of the Bane Act.  Plaintiffs allege that 
21  deputies ordered the female detainees to congregate together outside of the cells and then were 
22  taken in groups of three to separate bathroom stalls where they were ordered to remove their 
23  clothing, squat, cough, open their mouths, lift their breasts, and spread open their anuses for visual 
24  inspection for contraband materials.  Plaintiffs claim that at all times these visual inspections were 
25  conducted by female deputies but in the presence and view of between three and seven male 
26  deputies.  They also allege the searches were random, unnecessary, and unjustified in violation of 
27  the jail manual and federal law.   
28    The Court shall address other specific facts in the remainder of its order. 
2 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW   Document 114   Filed 12/05/22   Page 3 of 10
 
1  ANALYSIS 
2  A.  Legal Standard on Motion for Summary Judgment. 
3  Summary judgment is proper where the pleadings, discovery and affidavits show that there 
4  is “no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a 
5  matter of law.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(c).  Material facts are those which may affect the outcome of 
6  the case.  Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  A dispute as to a material 
7  fact is genuine if there is sufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to return a verdict for the 
8  nonmoving party.  
9  The party moving for summary judgment bears the initial burden of identifying those 
10  portions of the pleadings, discovery and affidavits which demonstrate the absence of a genuine 
11  issue of material fact.  Celotex Corp. v. Cattrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323 (1986).  When the moving 
12  party has met this burden of production, the nonmoving party must go beyond the pleadings and, 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  by its own affidavits or discovery, set forth specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  trial.  If the nonmoving party fails to produce enough evidence to show a genuine issue of material 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  fact, the moving party wins.  Id. 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  At summary judgment, the judge must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the 
S d nr
ee 17  nonmoving party: if evidence produced by the moving party conflicts with evidence produced by 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  the nonmoving party, the judge must assume the truth of the evidence set forth by the nonmoving 
19  party with respect to that fact.  Tolan v. Cotton, 572 U.S. 650, 656-57 (2014).   
20  B.  Outdoor Recreation Claims. 
21    It is undisputed that CJ2 lacks an outdoor recreation area and is located in downtown San 
22  Francisco.  It is also therefore undisputed that the facility cannot provide outdoor recreation 
23  opportunities to pretrial detainees in custody there.  Plaintiffs allege that the denial of outdoor 
24  recreation is a violation of their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment protections pursuant to 18 
25  U.S.C. section 1983, as well as implicating supervisory liability under Monell, and a violation of 
26  the California Bane Act, California Civil Code section 52.1(b).  Plaintiffs pray for relief, including 
27  punitive damages. 
28    Section 1983 provides a cause of action for violation of a plaintiff’s constitutional rights by 
3 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW   Document 114   Filed 12/05/22   Page 4 of 10
 
1  persons acting under the color of state law.  Nurre v. Whitehead, 580 F.3d 1087, 1092 (9th Cir. 
2  2009).  Plaintiffs contend that the lack of outdoor recreation options violates the Eighth and 
3  Fourteenth Amendments.  The Eighth Amendment applies only to post-conviction inmates.  
4  Consequently, the Court shall review the Fourteenth Amendment jurisprudence for Plaintiffs who 
5  are all pretrial detainees.  Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 535, n.16 (1979) (holding that when 
6  pretrial detainees challenge the condition of their confinement, the question is whether the 
7  conditions amount to punishment in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth 
8  Amendment); see also Frost v. Agnos, 152 F.3d 1124, 1128 (9th Cir. 1998 (citing Bell, 441 U.S. at 
9  535 n.16) (holding that the claims of pretrial detainees “are analyzed under the Fourteenth 
10  Amendment Due Process Clause, rather than under the Eighth Amendment.”).  The Fourteenth 
11  Amendment, furthermore, provides more protection than the Eighth Amendment because is 
12  “prohibits all punishment of pretrial detainees.”  Vasquez v. County of Kern, 949 F.3d 1153, 1163-
a 
tr in
uoro 13  64 (9th Cir. 2020) (quoting Demery v. Arpaio, 378 F.3d 1020, 1029 (9th Cir. 2004)).   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    For any particular governmental action to constitute punishment “(1) that action must 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  cause the detainee to suffer from harm or ‘disability,’ and (2) the purpose of the governmental 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  action must be to punish the detainee.”  Demery, 378 F.3d at 1029.  “If a particular condition or 
S d nr
ee 17  restriction of pre-trial detention is reasonably related to a legitimate governmental objective, it 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  does not, without more, amount to ‘punishment.’”  Bell, 441 U.S. at 539.  In order to “constitute 
19  punishment, the harm or disability caused by the government’s action must either significantly 
20  exceed, or be independent of, the inherent discomforts of confinement.”  Demery, 378 F.3d at 
21  1030.  
22    Under the Supreme Court’s decision in Bell, a jail’s primary obligations are to provide 
23  “adequate food, clothing, shelter, sanitation, medical care and personal safety.”  Bell, 441 U.S. at 
24  529 n.11.  The Ninth Circuit has held that courts must consider the conditions of confinement and 
25  has confirmed, “time and time again, that the Constitution requires jail officials to provide outdoor 
26  recreation opportunity, or otherwise meaningful recreation, to prison inmates.”  Shorter v. Baca, 
27  895 F.3d 1176, 1185 (9th Cir. 2018) (emphasis added).  The undisputed record in this case 
28  indicates that there is no option for outdoor exercise or outdoor recreation for inmates held in CJ2.  
4 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW   Document 114   Filed 12/05/22   Page 5 of 10
 
1  Thus, the only determination the Court must make is whether CJ2 provides otherwise meaningful, 
2  indoor exercise or recreation to its inmates. 
3    Although the Constitution provides that jails cannot deny inmates the opportunity for 
4  exercise, the Ninth Circuit has declined to determine that the Constitution requires a specific 
5  minimum amount of time for recreation for pretrial detainees.  See Pierce v. County of Orange, 
6  526 F.3d 1190, 1212 (9th Cir. 2008).  In Pierce, the jail had only provided ninety minutes of 
7  indoor exercise per week.  The court held that did not satisfy constitutional minimum and 
8  reinstated a prior injunction which required that the jail provide inmates two hours of indoor 
9  recreation per week.  Id. at 1212-13; see also Candler v. Santa Rita Cty. Jail Watch Commander, 
10  No. 11-CV-01992-CW, 2015 WL 333298, at *9 (N.D. Cal. Jan. 26, 2015) (holding that, under 
11  Pierce, providing two hours of recreation weekly met constitutional standards).  Further, “the 
12  constitutionality of conditions for inmate exercise must be evaluated based on the full extent of the 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  available recreational opportunities.”  Norbert v. City and County of San Francisco, 10 F.4th 918, 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  929 (9th Cir. 2021). 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    Accordingly, the Court finds that the provision of three hours of indoor recreation time per 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  week, distributed over time, does not violate constitutional limitations and is what the applicable 
S d nr
ee 17  state regulations require.  Title 15 of the California Code of Regulations sets out the requirement 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  of a minimum of three hours of recreation weekly for long-term inmates.  15 Cal. Code Regs. § 
19  1065.  The regulations specify that the recreation time must be “distributed over seven days.”  Id.  
20  The record before this Court indicates that although CJ2 provided three hours recreation time 
21  weekly to inmates, at least in 2020, it failed to distribute those hours over the seven days.  
22  (Declaration of Andrew Chan King, ¶ 9; Ex. L.)  Defendants provide undisputed evidence that the 
23  jail used to provide structured group movement and exercise classes three days a week for an hour, 
24  and also that the gym was available to inmates.  (Declaration of Marcela Espino (“Espino Decl.”), 
25  ¶ 2; Declaration of Jason Jackson (“Jackson Decl.”), ¶ 11.)  The gym has a treadmill, bikes, and 
26  resistance machines as well as a ping pong table and board games.  The gym also has a radio for 
27  inmates’ use and four bathroom stalls and sinks from which inmates can obtain water.  (Jackson 
28  Decl., ¶ 7.)  Exercise at the gym and structured group exercise classes have been suspended due to 
5 

Case 4:19-cv-07659-JSW   Document 114   Filed 12/05/22   Page 6 of 10
 
1  Covid-19 protocols.  (Id. at ¶ 12; Espino Decl., ¶ 5.)  Defendants indicate their intention to restart 
2  exercise classes in the fall of 2022.  (Espino Decl., ¶ 6.) 
3    In addition, the evidentiary record provides that inmates in the general population have 
4  several hours of free time per day (generally 4.5 hours during the weekdays and 8 hours during the 
5  weekend) to use the common areas in their residential pods.  (Jackson Declaration at ¶ 10.)  
6  During this free time, inmates are not confined to their cells and are permitted to recreate, 
7  including walking around the pod, reading, watching TV, playing board games, and making phone 
8  calls.  (Id.)  In addition, during this time, inmates are permitted to exercise in the pods, including 
9  doing push-ups, sit ups, squats, planks, lunges, etc.  (Id.)  None of the named plaintiffs dispute that 
10  they were permitted this recreation time.   
11     Based on this Court’s finding that the hours provided to inmates at CJ2 are sufficient to 
12  pass constitutional muster under existing precedent, the Court similarly finds that the Monell claim

19    The undisputed evidence before the Court, including video footage of one of the searches 
20  conducted on November 20, 2018, indicates that female pretrial detainees may have been 
21  subjected to incidental viewing by male deputies while undergoing strip searches.  Male deputies 
22  who were on duty in the pod during the searches were tasked with securing the pod and searching 
23  common areas while female deputies took groups of two to three inmates to a lower level 
24  bathroom with exterior glass walls for the searches.  (Declaration of Lt. Brian Krol (“Krol Decl.”), 
25  ¶¶ 11-15.)  All SFSO deputies are trained to minimize exposure of the inmates during the strip 
26  search process to anyone outside of the bathroom stall area, including blocking any opening with 
27  their bodies while a strip search is conducted.  (Id. at ¶ 19.)

3  were strip searched, but none testified that the male deputies were present in the immediate area of 
4  the searches or that they made lewd or inappropriate comments.   Of the named plaintiffs, only 
5  Plaintiff Pierce testified that she had observed male deputies looking in the direction of the

24    In Grummett, the Ninth Circuit considered an action brought by male inmates who alleged 
25  that female guards were viewing them in states of partial or total nudity while dressing, showering, 
26  being strip searched, using the toilet, all in violation of their right to privacy.  889 F.2d at 492.  
27  Female guards were not assigned to positions of frequent surveillance of the inmates but were 
28  found to be in positions requiring only infrequent and casual observation, or observation from a

1  distance.  Id. at 494.  The Ninth Circuit concluded that inmates had not demonstrated “restricted 
2  observations by members of the opposite sex [were] so degrading as to require intervention by this 
3  court” and ultimately found there was no Fourteenth Amendment violation.  Id.  Similarly, in 
4  Michenfelder, the Ninth Circuit considered a challenge to frequent, routine, cross-gender strip 
5  searches on the grounds they were unreasonable and violated the inmates’ right to privacy because 
6  they were conducted in the company of female deputies.  860 F.2d at 333.  In that case, although 
7  the female officers did not perform the non-emergent searches, they were stationed in positions 
8  controlling cell doors and monitoring the tiers via a video screen.  Id. at 330.  By virtue of their 
9  surveillance responsibilities, female officers could have, at most, an “indistinct, limited view” of 
10  the inmates through small windows in the cell doors or by watching the video monitors.  The court 
11  held that strip searches that involve infrequent or casual observation by members of the opposite 
12  gender, or where opposite gender observation is from a distance, do not unreasonably infringe

19  anytime a visual strip search is conducted in the bathrooms or shower stalls.  The Court finds that 
20  a reasonably jury could not find that incidental and casual viewing by the male deputies was so 
21  degrading as to amount to a constitutional violation. 
22    Based on this Court’s finding that the incidental cross-gender viewing during strip searches 
23  conducted at CJ2 pass constitutional muster under existing precedent, the Court similarly finds 
24  that the Monell claim and the Bane Act claims, which depend upon a finding of unconstitutional 
25  treatment, similarly fail.  The Court GRANTS Defendants’ motion for summary judgment on the 
26  cross-gender search claim.
